name: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), female
sourceNote: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), female
sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources.Website: http://w3.unece.org/pxweb/DATABASE/STAT/Gender.stat.asp

name: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), male
sourceNote: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), male
sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources.

name: Labor force participation rate for ages 15-24, female (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15-24 that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.  The participation rates are harmonized to account for differences in national data collection and tabulation methodologies as well as for other country-specific factors such as military service requirements. The series includes both nationally reported and imputed data and only estimates that are national, meaning there are no geographic limitations in coverage.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate for ages 15-24, male (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15-24 that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.  The participation rates are harmonized to account for differences in national data collection and tabulation methodologies as well as for other country-specific factors such as military service requirements. The series includes both nationally reported and imputed data and only estimates that are national, meaning there are no geographic limitations in coverage.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-64) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-64)
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate, male (% of male population ages 15-64) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate, male (% of male population ages 15-64)
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15+) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Ratio of female to male labor force participation rate (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate, male (% of male population ages 15+) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force participation rate, total (% of total population ages 15+) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15 and older that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Part time employment, female (% of total female employment)
sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Part time employment, male (% of total male employment)
sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Part time employment, female (% of total part time employment)
sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Part time employment, total (% of total employment)
sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with primary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with primary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with primary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force, female
sourceNote: Labor force, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimate using ratio from ILO's KILM and World Bank's population.

name: Labor force, female (% of total labor force)
sourceNote: Female labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which women are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force, total
sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, youth female (% of female labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment rate (% ages 15-24)
sourceNote: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment rate (% ages 15-24)
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, youth male (% of male labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Long-term unemployment, female (% of female unemployment)
sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Long-term unemployment, male (% of male unemployment)
sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Long-term unemployment (% of total unemployment)
sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with primary education, female (% of female unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with primary education, male (% of male unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with secondary education, female (% of female unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with secondary education, male (% of male unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with tertiary education, female (% of female unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment with tertiary education, male (% of male unemployment)
sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, female (% of female labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, male (% of male labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, total (% of total labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1,000 women ages 15-19)
sourceNote: Adolescent fertility rate is the number of births per 1,000 women ages 15-19.
sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

name: Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
sourceNote: Crude birth rate indicates the number of live births occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Death rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
sourceNote: Crude death rate indicates the number of deaths occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Contraceptive prevalence (% of women ages 15-49)
sourceNote: Contraceptive prevalence rate is the percentage of women who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, any form of contraception. It is usually measured for married women ages 15-49 only.
sourceOrganization: Household surveys, including Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys by UNICEF.

name: Mortality rate, infant, female (per 1,000 live births)
sourceNote: Infant mortality rate, female is the number of female infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 female live births in a given year.
sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

name: Mortality rate, infant (per 1,000 live births)
sourceNote: Infant mortality rate is the number of infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.
sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

name: Mortality rate, infant, male (per 1,000 live births)
sourceNote: Infant mortality rate, male is the number of male infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 male live births in a given year.
sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

name: Life expectancy at birth, female (years)
sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Life expectancy at birth, total (years)
sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
sourceOrganization: Derived from male and female life expectancy at birth from sources such as: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Life expectancy at birth, male (years)
sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Age at first marriage, female
sourceNote: Age at first marriage, female
sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys

name: Age at first marriage, male
sourceNote: Age at first marriage, male
sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys

name: Fertility rate, total (births per woman)
sourceNote: Total fertility rate represents the number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with current age-specific fertility rates.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Repot (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database

name: Wanted fertility rate (births per woman)
sourceNote: Wanted fertility rate is an estimate of what the total fertility rate would be if all unwanted births were avoided.
sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

name: Female headed households (% of households with a female head)
sourceNote: Female headed households shows the percentage of households with a female head.
sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

name: Women who were first married by age 18 (% of women ages 20-24)
sourceNote: Women who were first married by age 18 (% of women ages 20-24)
sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), AIDS Indicator Surveys(AIS), Reproductive Health Survey(RHS), and other household surveys.

name: Population ages 0-14, female
sourceNote: Population ages 0-14, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population ages 0-14 (% of total)
sourceNote: Population, age 0-14 (% of total) is the population between the ages of 0 and 14 as a percentage of the total population.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Population ages 15-64, female
sourceNote: Population ages 15-64, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population ages 15-64, male
sourceNote: Population ages 15-64, male
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population ages 15-64, total
sourceNote: Population ages 15-64, total
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Population ages 15-64 (% of total)
sourceNote: Total population between the ages 15 to 64 is the number of people who could potentially be economically active. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of the country of origin.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Population ages 65 and above, female
sourceNote: Population ages 65 and above, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population ages 65 and above (% of total)
sourceNote: Population ages 65 and above as a percentage of the total population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of the country of origin.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Age population, age 0, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 0, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 0, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 0, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 01, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 01, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 01, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 01, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 02, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 02, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 02, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 02, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 03, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 03, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 03, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 03, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 04, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 04, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 04, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 04, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 05, female, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 05, female, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Age population, age 05, male, interpolated
sourceNote: Age population, age 05, male, interpolated
sourceOrganization: UN World Population Prospects for years up to 2009, and World Bank for 2010 onwards.

name: Sex ratio at birth (females per 1,000 males)
sourceNote: Sex ratio at birth (females per 1,000 males)
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates based on the UN World Population Prospects.

name: Age dependency ratio (% of working-age population)
sourceNote: Age dependency ratio is the ratio of dependents--people younger than 15 or older than 64--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and ICF International.

name: Population, total
sourceNote: Total population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin. The values shown are midyear estimates.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report  (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Population, female
sourceNote: Population, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population, female (% of total)
sourceNote: Population, female (% of total) is the percentage of the population that is female.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Unmet need for contraception (% of married women ages 15-49)
sourceNote: Unmet need for contraception is the percentage of fertile, married women of reproductive age who do not want to become pregnant and are not using contraception.
sourceOrganization: Household surveys, including Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys by UNICEF.

name: Account at a formal financial institution, male (% age 15+)
sourceNote: Account at a formal financial institution, male (% age 15+)
sourceOrganization: Global Findex.

name: Account at a formal financial institution, female (% age 15+)
sourceNote: Account at a formal financial institution, female (% age 15+)
sourceOrganization: Global Findex.
